void:Dataset.dcterms:title: Ontology for the representation of medieval calendar data
void:Dataset.dc:title: Medieval Christian Calendars Ontology
void:Dataset.dc:creator: Dominique Stutzmann (dominique.stutzmann@irht.cnrs.fr)
Doug Emery
George Gordon
Elisabeth Raunig (elisabeth.raunig@uni-graz.at)
Georg Vogeler (georg.vogeler@uni-graz.at)

rdfs:Class.rdfs:comment: The Actor experiencing the religious event. It is typically (i) a saint as defined in http://dbpedia.org/ontology/Saint, and therefore a subClassOf E21_Person, (ii) a supernatural being (e.g. archangel Michael), (iii) different persons of God and Trinity (iv) a group of persons, and therefore a subClassOf E74_Group. The latter takes two main forms: a group that is known collectively (e.g. Forty Martyrs of Sebaste, or Eleven Thousand Virgins), or a group that is described with personal names, either in full (e.g. "Dionysii, Rustici et Eleutherii") or in reduced form (e.g. "Dionysii et socii ejus").
This class is to be used to indicate the name of the E39_Actor when the latter is not identified and a calendar entry allows only to link the name E41_Appellation

rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: The standardized given name of an E39_Actor

rdfs:Class.rdfs:comment: All events in the history related to God, the history of Salvation of mankind, the life of religious communities, and to the life and afterlife of a saint. This class comprises the events of the life of Christ, the manifestation of the Trinity in the history of mankind (e.g. Pentecost), and the life of religious communities (dedicatio ecclesiae), and the life and afterlife of saints (mainly death/natalis, but also elevatio), including the events related to their relics (inventio, translatio). The ReligiousEvent are typically connected to time and place. The properties declared by dbpedia.org with domain "saint" are mostly shortcuts for events, e.g. beatification (dbo:beatifiedBy, dbo:beatifiedDate, dbo:beatifiedPlace), canonization (dbo:canonizedBy, dbo:canonizedDate, dbo:canonizedPlace); some others are attached to the person or connect them to things and places (dbo:iconographicAttributes, dbo:majorShrine, dbo:veneratedIn). The sacraments, elections, transfers from a diocese to another, promotion to a higher dignity are ReligiousEvent(s) attached to date and place.

The feast as an abstract entity describing the concept of a religious event like the death of a saint considered to be commemorated. The following example taken from H. Grotefend illustrates how a feast relates to a ReligiousEvent and to a Celebration: "Marie nivis (ad nives) August 5: *Aquileja, *Erfurt, Gnesen, Hamburg, Krakau, Mainz, Merseburg, Naumburg, Ölmütz, *Prag, Schwerin, *Trient, Utrecht. - Beauvais, Nevers, Reims, Rouen, Tournai. - Mailand (Ambros.). - *Compostella, Tarassona, Toledo (Mozarab.). - *Aberdon, Salisbury. - Agram, Gran. - *Augustiner-Eremiten, *Benedictiner (Casinenser, Olivetaner), *Camaldulenser, *Carmeliter, *Domini ultramontani, *Franciscaner, *Pauliner. || August 4: *Sevilla. - Fünfkirchen. || August 12: Passau. || August 31: Meissen.". The name refers to the (miraculous) Event that the location of the church Santa Maria Maggiore, in honour of the Virgin Mary as protectress of Rome, was determined by the appearance of snow on the Esquiline Hill on a summer day (cf. https://www.catholicculture.org/culture/library/dictionary/index.cfm?id=36256). On the one hand, the ReligiousEvent is unique: the appearance of the snow occured once and has a unique date in time. On the other hand, each Ecclesiastical Unit has a Celebration and they are very diverse: differet ranks (here, higher ranks marked with "*"), different dates (Aug. 5, but also 4, 12, and even 31). There is no doubt that different ecclesiastical units were celebrating the same feast, referring to a common event, and for which all celebrations these celebrations were particular instantiations. Some Feast(s) refer losely to a ReligiousEvent. For example, the feast of Corpus Christi and the Sollemnitas Sacratissimi Cordis Iesu in early modern age. The former can refer to the Cene or to the vision of Juliana of Liège. The later is clearly linked to the vision of Saint Margaret Mary Alacoque, but is not a feast of this particular vision. Both are linked to an Actor (here to be considered as a Mystery, itself linked to Christ, rather than part of their body) and the ReligiousEvent can be either the particular revelation to one saint, or the general and progressive revelation of the Mystery (modelled as Actor).

Different views are represented on the Vigils and Octaves. In systems that do not differenciate between Feast ad Celebration, they are considered as another Feast. However, in handwritten notes, Denis Muzerelle indicates "+vigilia" or "+oct." as ranking of a Feast and do not repeat the information on the specific days. One can suggest that Vigils and Octaves are additional "Celebration"(s) for one unique "Feast".

The date of a Celebration can be fixed or moveable and, generally, depending on the Lunar cycle of Sundays, either immediately (e.g. first Sunday of Advent) or through the Easter cycle. In the latter case, calendar entries providing evidence for the Celebration may be positioned at a specific date. The most famous example is Easter, that is regularly inscribed in calendars at the date March, 25th.

According to the answer given to the definition of Feast for Vigils and Octaves, one can consider them as Celebration linked to a Feast, in which case the CelebrationDate is defined through the type of relation of Celebration to Feast.

rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: If "vigilia" and "octava" is considered a relation from Celebration to Feast, one should expand this part of the model
The type of religious event to celebrate, e.g. the transfer of relics ("translatio”).

rdfs:Class.rdfs:comment: The practice in a religious community to celebrate a feast.

Any part of text given by the “document” and making a statement, in particular about a celebration (connection of date+feast+community), but including other information (obits, annalistic notes, astrological or astronomical observations)

rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: Several entries may be recorded for a single day.

rdfs:Class.rdfs:comment: The CalendarTemporalStructure is typically a day, for which the calendar indicates which feasts should be celebrated and gives specifics about this celebration. It is also often a month for which statements can be made such as the length of the month and the moon.
The CalendarPhysicalStructure is typically a page. It could be used to record each line on a page.
The section in the source that is a witness of a text documenting the temporal distribution of religious practice.
The object comprising a calendar. Typically, it is a book in codex form, but it can be a foldable sheet of parchment or paper. It can be handwritten or printed.

The SourceIdentifier is typically composed of one of the following sets of information : (1) msIdentifier = settlement + repository + idno; (2) msIdentifier = msName; (3) bibl (if the source is edited and can be referred to)
The SourceEdition describes any type of edition, partial or in full, that provide information of the specific content of a specific Sources

rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: The temporal relationship between a celebration and the standard chronological place of a feast (e.g. "octava", "vigilia")
Feast can be celebrated in relation to other feasts, e.g. the vigilia on the evening of the feast.

rdfs:Class.rdfs:comment: A religious community defined by personal membership instead of geographical
A geo-political unit
The full orbis christianus

A text documenting the temporal distribution of religious practice. This texts may be instantiated in several copies or witnesses, which are in the Source class. In this context, it is a system of organizing days through a year.
A calendar in practice in a specific diocese.
A calendar in practice in a religious order.

rdf:Property.rdfs:comment: The saint can be identified by a ecclesiastical function at a specific place (e.g. bishop in ...)
The saint can be identified by a religious/ecclesiastical function
